content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Scientists study a population that experiences variations in its rate of growth. The rate of growth of the population is modeled by the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of P with respect to t, equals, P times, 0.02 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 30, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, t plus 10, close parenthesis, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>·</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mspace width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days since the observation of the population began. Let <math alttext="P equals, f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> be the particular solution to the given differential equation satisfying <math alttext="f of 50, equals 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>50</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.(a) A slope field for the given differential equation is shown. Sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 50 comma 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Scientists study a population that experiences variations in its rate of growth. The rate of growth of the population is modeled by the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of P with respect to t, equals, P times, 0.02 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 30, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, t plus 10, close parenthesis, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>·</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mspace width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days since the observation of the population began. Let <math alttext="P equals, f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> be the particular solution to the given differential equation satisfying <math alttext="f of 50, equals 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>50</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.(a) A slope field for the given differential equation is shown. Sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 50 comma 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.

(b) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="P equals, f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) It is known that <math alttext="f prime of t is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math alttext="f double prime of t is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math> on the interval <math alttext="47 less than t, less than 51" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>47</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>51</mn></math>. If the tangent line found in part (b) is used to approximate <math alttext="f of 48" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>48</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, is the approximation an underestimate or an overestimate for the actual value of <math alttext="f of 48" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>48</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Use separation of variables to find the particular solution <math alttext="P equals, f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of P with respect to t, equals, P times, 0.02 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 30, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, t plus 10, close parenthesis, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>·</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mspace width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> that satisfies <math alttext="f of 50, equals 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>50</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.

topic.text: 2.2: Defining the Derivative of a Function and Using Derivative Notation

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
